descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Prof. Druckman "Sports, Politics, and Public Opinion" Winter 2016 First-year Seminar

Sports and politics have become increasingly intertwined over the last 40 years. Local, state, and federal governments as well as other governing bodies (e.g., the NCAA) regulate who can participate (e.g., eligibility, equality) and what standards players must meet (e.g., drug testing, academic performance). These organizations also oversee economic (e.g., stadiums) and symbolic (e.g., mascots) issues. Ideally, governing policies would be responsive to the wishes of their constituents (e.g. players, owners, voters). But are they? How would we know? How do we gauge their opinions? Alternatively, how do sports affect public opinion? Do citizens prefer politicians who engage in sports? Do media portrayals of sport affect what citizens think about race and/or gender? These are examples of the questions we will consider in this class. This involves learning the science of public opinion polling and then applying this knowledge to study opinions about public policies relevant to sports.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: How to design a public opinion study. Understand how to systematically study the relationship between sports and politics, using social science methods.
